related_questions.question: What causes a callus on your toe?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Ill-fitting shoes: . Opens in new tabShoes that are too tight or too loose can cause the toes to rub against the shoe or other toes, leading to friction and pressure.
High heels: . Opens in new tabHigh-heeled shoes can force the toes into an unnatural position, increasing pressure and friction.
Walking patterns: . Opens in new tabCertain walking styles or activities like running can also put extra pressure on specific areas of the foot.
Bony prominences: . Opens in new tabConditions like bunions or hammertoe can cause the bones to press against the skin, leading to calluses.
Dry skin: . Opens in new tabDry skin is more susceptible to calluses, as it's less flexible and more easily irritated.
The thickened skin, or callus, is the body's natural defense against injury.
It acts as a cushion, protecting the underlying tissues from further friction and pressure.
Foot abnormalities: Flat feet or high arches can alter the way weight is distributed on the foot, increasing pressure on certain areas.
Obesity: Excess weight can put additional stress on the feet.
Older age: Skin becomes thinner and less elastic with age, making it more vulnerable to calluses.
Medical conditions: Certain conditions like diabetes can affect blood flow and skin health, making individuals more prone to calluses.

text_blocks.snippet: To get rid of a callus on your toe, start by soaking your foot in warm, soapy water for 5-10 minutes to soften the callus. Then, gently rub the callus with a pumice stone, foot file, or emery board, being careful not to over-file and damage the surrounding skin. After filing, apply a moisturizing lotion or cream, particularly those containing urea or salicylic acid, to help soften and exfoliate the area. Wearing properly fitting shoes and using padded inserts or moleskin can help prevent calluses from recurring.
snippet_highlighted_words: soaking your foot in warm, soapy water for 5-10 minutes to soften the callus.
Then, gently rub the callus with a pumice stone, foot file, or emery board, being careful not to over-file and damage the surrounding skin.
After filing, apply a moisturizing lotion or cream, particularly those containing urea or salicylic acid, to help soften and exfoliate the area

list.snippet: Soak your foot in warm, soapy water for 5-10 minutes to soften the callus.
This can be done in a basin, tub, or even in the shower.
Adding Epsom salts to the water can further help soften the skin.
Use a pumice stone, foot file, or emery board to gently file down the callus.
Wet the pumice stone or file before using it and apply light to medium pressure.
Avoid over-filing, as this can irritate the skin.
File in one direction, or in a circular motion, to remove dead skin.
After filing, dry your foot thoroughly.
Apply a moisturizing lotion or cream, especially those containing urea, salicylic acid, or ammonium lactate.
These ingredients help soften the skin and promote exfoliation.
Consider applying a thick moisturizer like petroleum jelly overnight and covering your foot with a cotton sock to enhance absorption.
Wear shoes that fit properly and provide adequate cushioning.
Avoid shoes that are too tight or narrow, as they can cause friction and pressure on the toes.
Consider using padded inserts or moleskin to protect the area from friction.
Keep toenails trimmed to prevent them from pushing against the shoe and causing irritation.
If calluses persist or become painful, consult a podiatrist for further evaluation and treatment options.
